paragraph.paragraph: When sending requests to the database, the request is first parsed then executed. Instead of parsing many times the same requests, i.e. with only changes in expression values, most of RDBMS enable to precompile requests. These requests can then be executed as routines and are identified by a name and a signature.
EiffelStore lets you use stored procedures with /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_proc_flatshort.xmlDB_PROC class to:
paragraph.heading: 2Executing a stored procedure

list.item:
Create a /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_proc_flatshort.xmlDB_PROC object and load the stored procedure you want to use:
procedure: DB_PROC ... create procedure.make ("UPDATE") procedure.load if procedure.exists then ... end

Execute the procedure through a /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_selection_chart.xmlDB_SELECTION (if a result is expected) or a /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_change_chart.xmlDB_CHANGE object (otherwise).
Note: Requests with a result (/libraries/store/reference/interface/db_selection_chart.xmlDB_SELECTION) or without (/libraries/store/reference/interface/db_change_chart.xmlDB_CHANGE) are both abstract expressions. DB_PROC executes an abstract expression using an object of /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_expression_chart.xmlDB_EXPRESSION type, which corresponds to an abstract expression. /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_selection_chart.xmlDB_SELECTION and /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_change_chart.xmlDB_CHANGE inherits from /libraries/store/reference/interface/db_expression_chart.xmlDB_EXPRESSION. You can execute your request mostly like a basic one:
Create your request.
Bind request variables. Variables are stored procedure arguments.
Note: Take a look at how to
../60_query_variables/index.xml bind variables to a query.
Execute the query through the DB_PROC object.
procedure: DB_PROC expr: DB_CHANGE ... procedure.execute (expr) expr.clear_all
Check for errors and load result if any.

paragraph.heading: 2Creating a stored procedure
paragraph.paragraph:
DB_PROC also enables you to create or drop stored procedures:
Use store to create a procedure.
Use drop to delete one. The following example shows how to overwrite a procedure in the database:
paragraph.code_block:
procedure: DB_PROC
... create procedure.make ("NEW_PROCEDURE") procedure.load if procedure.exists then procedure.drop end procedure.load if not procedure.exists then procedure.set_arguments (<<"one_arg">>, <<"">>) procedure.store ("update contacts set firstname = one_arg where contactid = 1") end
